text:
- On this episode of
"Innovation Ambassadors,"
we're showcasing the journey of Experian,

a leading global
information services company
providing data and analytical tools
to clients around the world.
We'll explore their work
with the AWS innovation team in Australia
on harnessing the power of the AWS Cloud

to create better brand
experiences for their consumers.

Well, I'm excited to welcome
from Experian Marcio Goncalves,
head of product development.

Marcio, thanks so much for
being here today with us.
- Thank you. It's good to be here.
- And also from Experian,
we have Jo Kennedy, engineering leader.
Jo, thanks for being here.

- My pleasure. Thank you
for having my company.
- And joining us from AWS,
we have Jesse Mulvogue,
who is the senior account manager
in our Enterprise Greenfield segment
based in Melbourne, Australia.
Jesse, thanks for joining us.
- Great to be here. Thanks.

- So, Marcio, for our
international listeners,

maybe you can tell us a little
bit about what Experian does.
- Sure.

Experian is a global
information services company.

We work in Australia with
their marketing services unit

and we help brands
create better experiences
to their own consumers,
and obtaining value from data

is where we particularly
enjoy helping our clients,
whether it's enhancing their data sets
or providing insights

to help drive their
marketing dollar further.
So that's who we are.
- Wonderful.
And what were some of the challenges
that led you to work with AWS?
- That's an interesting one.
When we started a few years ago,
we were pretty much working
on, like, old-school environments.

So it was like databases,
SQL server environments,
where people just like query the data,
not in the most efficient ways.
And the experience for our clients,

we deal with data, so
we have to process data,

everything was very manual,
including the deliveries,

which was not the greatest
of the experiences.

Everything was a file
being sent over to a client
to ingest in their own databases,
which presents its own difficulties,

and the scalability issues
that come with them,

not only for us because everything
is manual, not scalable,
but also for our clients,
which had a sometimes a difficulty

ingesting the results
of what we do for them.
- Sure, yeah.
And Jo, maybe you can set a little bit
of that technology landscape for us
and where you were trying to go.
- Sure.
So as Marcio mentioned,

when he and I joined this
team about four years ago,

it was all on-premise SQL
servers, lots of manual work,
lots of undocumented stored procedures,
and it was a very legacy landscape.
Over the past few years,

we have moved over to
a cloud-first mindset.

We're now dealing with
data in vast volumes
compared to what we had previously.
And we're able to do that now

because the cloud gives
us that scalability,
gives us that processing power

that we just didn't have
with the previous systems.

- Hmm, and so building that
additional scalability in

and looking at ways to automate
those more manual processes

was one of the, it sounds
like the challenge here.
- Absolutely.
Automation of processes
and automation of maintenance as well.

I'm sure you can imagine
lots of on-premise servers,
there's a big effort
just to keep those updated
with things like security patches,

you know, nevermind doing
anything really interesting,
whereas now we're moving to cloud

and moving away from service
to a serverless mindset,

it really frees up our
time to do the fun stuff.
- Yeah, absolutely.
So Jesse, maybe take us from there.

Marcio comes to you with
this pretty complex challenge

that he's trying to
address for the business.
Where did you go from there?
- So I think we really needed
to understand the problem more deeply,

and at Amazon, we do things
a little bit differently.

So it's our job to go
where there's ambiguity
and really help the customer test ideas
and try and help drive clarity.
It seems like

working backwards-
- Absolutely.
- Would be a great mechanism for that.
- Yeah, yes, for sure.

So that working backwards
mechanism that we use internally,

we also share with our
customers, don't we?
- So maybe talk through a little bit

about how you brought that
working backwards mechanism
into a workshop

as I understand it, yeah?
- Sure, sure.

So we got together with
the innovation team,

gathered a number of Experian's
experts in their teams,

so people that understood
their customer deeply,
which involved a number of stakeholders
and calendarizing that.

We had people from marketing,
data engineers, and analytics.

And working backwards is
just a great mechanism

because it makes us
focus on the end customer
and, you know, workshop ideas,
but also just walk in their shoes.
- Mm, absolutely.

Developing that empathy
for our end customer.
And Marcio, as I understand it,
that was really important to you

to, like, have that
customer-centric approach

to the solutions you were trying
to drive for your business.
Is that right?
- Absolutely.
It's perhaps one of the top points,
having this customer-centric approach,

and clarity of vision, I'd
say, comes right in second.
In Experian, we do so many things
and we try,

in the end, we try to solve
a problem for our clients
in the best way possible.

When we have such a wide
and diverse set of opinions
about how to do it,
that it sometimes it creates misalignment
and people will have different ways
to land on a solution for our client.
I think working backwards helps us
or forces us to be on the same page,

which in the end streamlines
the development work.
- Mm, so how was that experience for you?
Talk us through a little bit
about what that workshop was like
and what came out of it.
- I think in a nutshell,

we want to make our clients'
experiences smoother.
We deal with a ton of different data sets
from our clients, ours, products,

to try helping the clients
get value out of their data,

and like I said, usually
we will send files
out to our clients,

but that's not the easiest
way for them to use.

And plus, this way we don't
get to see how they use it

and we don't get to
see how they figure out
what the parts they like

and, perhaps the most important,
the parts they don't like.

So we don't have insight
over the experience.

So we were on a mission not
just to fix the experience,

but also to make sure it was
user friendly and helpful
to who was using it in the end.
- Yeah, absolutely.
And that it was something

that could scale to
across the world, yeah?
- I think it's, definitely,
like if the client is happy about it,
if we can measure,
if everybody's on the same page,
scalability becomes kinda a consequence.

- Then the next step was
to actually write all this

and clarify our thinking
in a press release.
Is that right?
- Yeah, that's correct.

We wanted to have
everybody on the same page.

I think not only the press
release helped with that
in putting what was the vision,
what we were trying to achieve,

but also the how, like,
the press release is,
well, is incredibly useful.

I think for me the most important
part was actually the FAQ,
which forces people to spend energy
in answering the right questions,

answering the difficult
questions ahead of time

so everybody, like, is
forced into the same page,
forced to be on the alignment,

they understand deeply
the problem to be solved

and, most important,
what's the right tool set
to solve that problem.
- Right, right.
So the press release, very aspirational,
setting that vision,
and then the frequently asked questions,

getting to the driving
clarity of vision, yeah.
- It kind of expresses,

like doing the PR FAQ
before the product release

expresses the concept of working
backwards quite strongly.

Because usually a
frequently asked question

is something that happens,
you know, in the future,
whereas we actually did it in advance.
So you're really

thinking through-
- Absolutely.
- What that experience is.
- That's right, Jesse,
and I really love that the same is true
of the press release, right?
We actually write the press release
before we write any code,

as if something, we put
ourselves in the future
and in the shoes of our end customer
and try to express the value
as it relates to their experience, right?
- Absolutely.
- So we have this PR and FAQ.

What's the next step,
Jesse, in the journey?

- So the next step was really
just to get everyone together
for the data discovery workshop.
It was an opportunity for us to map out
the universe of data sources for Experian.
And again, Experian were very involved.

Involved I think we had
four or so from their team
and three from AWS

and it just gave us an
opportunity to understand
what we would do in the next stage,

which is designing and
architecting a build
for a deeper data discovery workshop.

- So Jo, maybe you can take
us through the architecture,
the high level architecture,
that came out of this workshop.
- Sure.

So it is this self-service
data delivery API,
and that is API gateway at the front,
a bunch of lambda functions behind it,
DynamoDB for the metadata storage,
and then for the actual file delivery,

one of those lambda functions
calls out to Snowflake,
which is our data warehouse,

based on the configuration
that's been selected.
The data then gets unloaded to S3

and is served back to the
client via a pre-assigned URL.
- Hmm.
And that architecture, Marcio, allowed you
to create a system
that your customers could interact with,
is that right?
- Yeah, not only that,

but achieved the
scalability we always wanted

as the clients can come
and interact with it
without us having to intervene
and be stated together in a manual way.

So they just can come and
select the layouts they prefer,
what they want from the data.
It was just so much easier to handle,

which gave us these extra
capacity to implement,
like create improvements,
create more behind the scenes
instead of maintaining existing.
- Right. Right.

Now, we often talk in this
podcast about experimentation

also sometimes having
failures in it, right?
It wouldn't be an experiment
if we knew what the outcome was, right?
There's always challenges along the way.
Maybe there was something here
that you'd wanna share with our listeners.
- Yeah, curiously,

the outcome of this
working backwards session
was not put into production straight away.
We pivoted to a number of other projects
in which we used the same methodology
and they are in production right now
and we are using the same framework
to go about the problem, to solve it,
to get people alignment,
and to build basically the experience
in falling in love with the methodology

because it achieves
clarity in an environment
where you have a diversity of opinions.
It really helps us streamline
and focus on one problem at a time.
Not to mention it allows us

to, like, build fast
and fail fast if needed.
- Mm, mm.
And so yeah, that ambiguity,

bringing clarity to ambiguity,
right, with the process.

So what was the stumbling
block or challenge
that you had experienced?
- We've been for years selling solutions
that involve manually taking clients' data
and helping them
and then sending a file back to them.
So the whole process is very manual
or used to be very manual.
When we introduced an API in the middle,

people would were just
not ready to sell it
or to talk about it to their client
and enablement was a challenge.
How do you enable your go-to markets team

when talking about this
one with their clients?
And it made us, it made us realize
that we were, like, we're fast.
We're, like, faster than we ever been.
And that one was provided as a learning
on how to do the next one,
which was much better.

We involved the things that
we missed on the first time

and we did it again and
that one came out right.

But it made us realize
how faster we can move
and how faster we can learn.
- Mm. Right, right.
I love that, iterating on an approach
that looked very promising, but then,

and we often talk about
this, don't we, Jesse,
in the working backwards process
that it's an iterative process.

We test and validate
and then improve, right?

- Test and validate to
try to help drive clarity

and people and culture
are often the challenge.
Something that I'm just thinking of
while I'm sitting here
is that, you know, maybe we could have,
like, another workshop at some point
where we focus on that next challenge,
which is, you know, sales team enablement
and how to help them pick that up

and, you know, wrap their
arms around our experience

and then how they can better
improve their experience
of their customers.
- Absolutely.
So Marcio, what's next?
It sounds like you've deployed
several systems into production
and continuing to iterate and improve.
- Yes.
After the first session,

the first working backwards
discovery and the build,

we built probably another
couple of projects
that are already in production.

We're gonna embark on
another one right next.

So for us, it's a matter of,
like, keep learning, iterating.

I think this first one opened
a path for so many projects

and it gave us this,
like, speed that we needed
and this scalability.

So I think for us next is we
want to expand this methodology

across our unit, across
the company, hopefully,

and get them to benefit from
this in the same way we did.
- Wonderful, and Jo, on your side,

that architectural pattern
that you established
in that first data discovery lab,
that's something that you're using

and replicating in other
systems, is that right?
- Yeah, absolutely.
Yeah, we have another API in production,
which has a fairly similar architecture

and we've also taken
elements of that pattern

into a new feature which
we've just gone live with
in another product.
- Great.
Well, Marcio, Jo, and Jesse,
thank you so much for being here today
and sharing your story with us.
And I'm just wondering

if you had any words of
wisdom or reflections

that you would want to
share with our listeners?
I'll start with you, Jesse.
- I think from a AWS perspective,

I think it's important
to set that expectation

that a workshop like working
backwards in data discovery
does take time.
When you wanna work on a problem

and really spend some time
diving deep into that abyss,
it can be a scary place to go.

It's important to have
a high level of trust
so that you can really try to deliver
the outcome that you're looking for.
- Absolutely.
Jo, how about you?
What were your key learnings?
- My biggest takeaway from this project

is just how fast you can
build transformative product
if you're given the space to focus on it
and the right tooling.
I've been with Experian for 15 years now
and we had never built products as fast

as we have done in the
last couple of years.
It's really amazing.
- Fantastic.
Love the power of getting rid
of the undifferentiated heavy lifting,
letting the cloud take care of that,
and you and your team able to focus

on providing value to
your end customers, yeah.
Marcio, final words for you?
- Well, I second what Jesse and Jo said.
I think it's a matter of trust.
We need to set the expectations correctly
that whatever you're doing might fail,

but if it fails, you
learn a lot through it
and you do it fast in such a way you can,
it's an iterative process.
It's not a close-knit loop in the end.

And focus, absolute undisputed
focus in what you're doing.
It's imperative and it gets you there.
It answers these questions fast.

Like, it's not a, it's
not a low energy process.

You put a lot of energy, but
the rewards are well worth it.
- Absolutely.
And Marcio and Jo, I know Experian's
all about creating a better tomorrow.

Good luck to you on all
of the work that you'll do
on behalf of your customers,
and thank you all for being with us today.
- Thanks, Sara.
- Thanks a lot.
- Thank you.
(bright music)
(bright music)
- I'd like to thank our listeners
for coming on today's journey with us.
Look for future episodes of our podcast
on your favorite podcast platform.

Share your ideas for future
episodes or comments on this one
via the email in the description.
Thank you.
(bright music continues)
